repnme.cdata!:
Pakistan - Balochistan Natural Resource
            Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment conveys an unsatisfactory
            project outcome, unlikely sustainability, modest
            institutional development impacts, and, unsatisfactory
            performances, both by the Bank and Borrower. Lessons first
            outline that in an institutional environment of weak
            interagency, operational collaboration, low motivation,
            displacement of resources, inadequate technical, and program
            management capacity, a single project with multiple
            implementing agencies, and varied components, should be
            avoided: the cost of inter-agency conflicts, outweighs the
            expected benefits from inter-agency coordination. As an
            indication, placement of a single Special Account with a
            coordinating agency, impeded the progress of implementation,
            and provided grounds for interagency conflicts, affecting
            the flow of funds, and approval of expenditures. It is
            suggested significant benefits can be derived by addressing
            financial management issues at appraisal, to ensure
            accountability, disbursement arrangements, and procedures
            that facilitate project implementation. Furthermore, the
            design of operational subprojects was not linked with
            institutional objectives, hence, outputs were restricted to
            physical targets, Instead, the project's technical
            assistance, which will not have a sustainable impact, should
            have been included in the institutional building process,
            with responsibility over subproject line-agency operations.
            Other lessons address capacity building issues, compliance
            with the Bank's operational directives, delayed
            procurement of civil works, goods, and services, and,
            identification of appropriate community participation, and
            involvement among community sub-groups.

repnme.cdata!:
Pakistan - Balochistan Natural Resource
            Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project is the first phase in an
            expected long-term program of World Bank Group support to
            improve Balochistan's protection of its environment and
            management of its natural resources. The project will
            strengthen Balochistan's institutions involved with
            environmental protection and natural resource use so they
            are better able to undertake their responsibilities;
            strengthen local communities and involve them in the design
            and implementation of natural resources development and
            management; improve provincial natural resources use
            policies so that natural resources are used in an efficient
            and sustainable manner; publicize environmental issues; and
            implement high priority operations and pilot programs to
            rehabilitate and develop damaged natural resources. The
            pilot programs are designed according to the objectives and
            strategies of Pakistan's National Conservation
            Strategy. They will allow policy formulators to monitor the
            effects of current policies and, if necessary, develop or
            change them over time. The project will also provide
            training to upgrade staff's skills, technical
            assistance to help with project implementation, and funds to
            prepare future natural resource management projects.
